meanings.def: to run, drive, etc. after somebody/something in order to catch them or it
examples: chase somebody/something My dog likes chasing rabbits.
The kids chased each other around the kitchen table.
We were chased by a bull while crossing the field.
chase after somebody/something He chased after the burglar but couldn't catch him.
The boys were chasing each other around the yard.
They chased after the burglar but didn't catch him.

meanings.def: to force somebody/something to run away
examples: Chase the cat out—we don't want her in the kitchen.
This particular fish chases off any other fish that enters its territory.

meanings.def: to try to obtain or achieve something, for example money, work or success
examples: Too many people are chasing too few jobs nowadays.
The team is chasing its first win in five games.

meanings.def: to try to persuade somebody to have a sexual relationship with you
examples: chase after somebody Kevin's been chasing after Joan for months.
chase somebody Girls are always chasing him.

meanings.def: to persuade somebody to do something that they should have done already
examples: I need to chase him about organizing the meeting.
I've been chasing around town all morning looking for a present for Sharon.

meanings.def: to cut patterns or designs on metal
examples: chased silver

meanings.def: to be very busy but in fact achieve very little

idioms.def: to be very busy but in fact achieve very little

meanings.def: an act of running or driving after somebody/something in order to catch them or it
examples: The thieves were caught by police after a short chase.
a high-speed car chase
We lost him in the narrow streets and had to give up the chase (= stop chasing him).
to take up the chase (= start chasing somebody)
The chase is on!
Several children joined in the chase.
She ran in chase of the pram.
The film ends with a long car chase.
The movie opens with an exciting chase scene.

meanings.def: a process of trying hard to get something
examples: Three teams are involved in the chase for the championship.
the title chase
What did he really want? Was it just the thrill of the chase?
She enjoyed the thrill of the chase.
Exhausted and hungry, the hunters finally gave up the chase.

meanings.def: a long race in which horses have to jump over fences, water, etc.
a long race in which people run and jump over gates and water, etc. around a track
to stop wasting time and start talking about the most important thing
examples: Right, let's cut to the chase. How much is it going to cost?

meanings.def: to run after somebody/something in order to catch them
examples: We gave chase along the footpath.
The old lady shouted for help and then gave chase.
